fullText: Goofiness is at an all-time high in director Josh Rhodesâ€™ iteration of the time-cherished musical comedy. Good morning, and wecome to Broadway Newsâ€™ Broadway Review by Brittani Samuel â€” our overview of reactions, recommendations and information tied to last nightâ€™s Broadway opening of â€œSpamalot.â€ There is something liberating for both artists and audiences about a Broadway show that refuses, even for a moment, to take itself seriously. The mission becomes plain: Our objective is joviality. â€œSpamalotâ€ is the prime example. In this new staging, director-choreographer Josh Rhodes squeezes every drop of talent out of his all-star cast of comedy heavy hitters. Actors â€” especially the dextrous Ethan Slater, who pulls off a litany of roles in his track â€” prance, tumble and grovel across the St. James stage, hurling their bodies and modulating their voices to pry every laugh possible from Eric Idleâ€™s book. Idle keeps a grand chunk of the topsy-turvy dialogue and irreverent lyrics that won him and his fellow creators a Tony Award for Best Musical in 2005, but coyly adds some satirical jabs at todayâ€™s society. The show also carries the same self-awareness of its pitfalls, most notably the frivolous care of the sole female lead: the Lady of the Lake (Leslie Rodriguez Kritzer). Kritzer, a vocal stuntwoman, chomps through her standout number â€œDivaâ€™s Lamentâ€ â€” which calls out the showâ€™s writers â€” while sparkling as bright as the â€œRenaissance Tourâ€-evoking costumes that designer Jen Caprio drapes her in. Idle garnishes the show with a sprig of a political â€œpoint.â€ James Monroe Iglehartâ€™s King Arthur (however warmhearted) is a dotish monarch who canâ€™t accomplish anything alone. But, ultimately, the show is a spoof of its own form, mimicking other famous musicals and reiterating the underlying message found within all of them: â€œBe yourself.â€ But trust me, youâ€™ll barely catch wind of any sincerity between the firing squad of hilarious antics and the flurry of large-scale scenic changes. Youâ€™ll be too busy stumbling out of the St. James â€” jaw aching, mind spinning as if youâ€™ve been shot out of a cannon. Or, more likely, a catapult. BACKGROUND â€œSpamalotâ€ is a riff on the 1975 film â€œMonty Python and the Holy Grail,â€ one in a series of projects created by the loveable British comedy troupe, the Pythons. The group â€” made up of genre titans Graham Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Eric Idle, Terry Jones and Michael Palin â€” became massive clowns of their generation while performing on British television, but cemented their global success with the theatrical adaptation we know today as â€œSpamalot.â€ The original Broadway production debuted in 2005, won three Tony Awards and paved the way for a large-scale mounting at the Kennedy Center as part of its Broadway Center Stage series in spring 2023. That staging, also choreographed and directed by Rhodes, transferred to Broadway, so it boasts many of the same cast members and designers working on the show in New York City today. PLOT A plot is oft considered to be a chronological sequence of narrative events, so the term feels like a generous description of what â€œSpamalotâ€ follows. The show opens in 932 A.D. England where King Arthur sets out to round up a group of noble knights. As Idleâ€™s lyrics tell us plainly, England is in turmoil â€” disease, dissent and deprivation run amok. Arthurâ€™s goal to bring order is quickly sideswept, however, by a debaucherous visit to Camelot (Idleâ€™s garish version of the Vegas strip), a quest assigned by God to find a Holy Grail, looney bands of opposing knights and, oh yeah, Arthurâ€™s own wedding. Sequence quickly flies off the rails to make room for slapstick-riddled satire and Monty Python staples. Throughout both acts, characters mockingly reference other notable musicals (watch out â€œWicked,â€ â€œWest Side Story,â€ â€œThe Phantom of the Operaâ€), which makes it all the more meta-theatrically delicious when the show culminates in the Lady of the Lake revealing to King Arthur that they are all also in a Broadway show. The hyper-broad comedy resonates across gender, ethnicity, geography and every other identifier one can imagine: Silliness is universal. Similar shows that have this sweeping appeal are â€œGutenberg!
